title: Women in international business
segmentation: Ladies and gentlemen, please stand.
With the third session of our conference, women in business.
We've got four speeches here, beginning with Jane Massey.
did I pronounce this?
Click click it.
Thank you.
Chief executive officer.
Join Mercy is the UK's most experienced ROI practitioner.
She has been working in and as an evaluator in the domain of learning and development since 1993.

She has extensive experience in consulting on change management for international business in many sectors, and she also has extensive experience in evaluating research into workplace learning and labor market interventions for national governments.
EU and NSF funded programs please change the forces.
Thank you very much, Charlie.
I can't tell you what pleasure is been actually being here in the last couple of days.
It's.
I moved to live in the UK at the end of 99 and 98 beginning of 99 prior to that had lived in Ireland and spent three or four days a week in Brussels for a number of years.
I one of the things I realized when I moved to the UK in the first year to 18 months, particularly there was how much I missed the company of women.
And that is that is interesting.
My adult life in particular has been hugely enriched by the Company of women, and I think sometimes we don't celebrate enough.
How much?
We enrich one another's lives, and it's a great pleasure to spend a great pleasure being here in the company of great women.
Lots of different shades and views, and so forth, but it's been very nice.
I thought very long and hard, but what I had to contribute to this debate when you invited me on.
I think I'm going to say.
I need to I need to start by telling you a little bit about what we do my own background and the business that I run before I respond to the questions that we were asked to address.
I run this small company in Cambridge.
It is actually rapidly growing.
One of my challenges at the moment is how do I manage a fast growing business and most of our customers.
Most of our clients are big multinationals.
The big telecoms, the big banks.
Big engineering companies.
Those kinds of businesses.
I've been self-employed since 1993.

Firstly, I ran a business in Ireland between 93 and 99 and then just explaining earlier my my children had grown up at that point and after what my now husband calls an 18 year feasibility study, I decided to get married again and he happened to live in Cambridge.
So I ended up moving to Cambridge because we had family obligations to his family and it was a very good thing to do.
But I've I've always been rather unemployable.
I think that's the truth.
I tried to start my own business at 19.
Had no idea how to set up a business, but but did it anyway.
And then I went back to University and stayed in academic life for a bit and then I haven't had a three and a four year old.
Then I needed to earn a living for us full time and for lots of reasons I went back into.
I went into business.
I went into economic development.
And then I went back into being self employed and running my own business, but I think largely I'm one of those people who always asked the question.
Why are we doing this?
And there's it's not.
It's not for a little while.
Most businesses quite like people who challenge the status quo.

But if you get to be known as the person who's always asking the question, always saying why aren't they wearing any clothes when everybody says their magnificently dressed, then you get to be troublesome.
And you realize, actually, I'm better off as a self employed or running my own business?
'cause actually I'm more disruptive.

And the interesting thing is I've discovered since I've been self employed or running my own businesses, people are prepared to pay me quite a lot of money to come and say, why aren't you wearing any clothes?
Which is quite ironic and it's one of the great ironies of consulting that you know, you can't say it inside, but you can often say it from outside.
The other thing I wanted was part of what I've done right.
The way through the 1990s and right up until her within three or four weeks ago, I think was the last.
Framework program I've been involved in evaluating framework projects.
Also involved in evaluating social fund programs.
Social Fund progress on program projects and as mentioned earlier, and a little bit of work for the National Science Foundation, that's an evaluator as well.
And I've seen a lot of investment and my area of domain is largely around learning and development.
Learning at work knew workplace changes, ways of working.
There has been from time to time a specific gender dimension, but most of the programs I run.
Oh, evaluate on related to specifically to gender issues, so would be about knowledge, SoC information, SoC learning, development, adult learning, workplace learning and I have to say just.
One of the things I have notice around gender is that today, as an evaluator of framework programs, we tend to take equality and diversity issues much more seriously.
I remember the first time I was brought in as evaluator at the end of the Esprit program, she long time ago.
I was for years.

Actually, I would be the only woman in the room of maybe 12:15 twenty people both presenting projects and evaluating, and the idea that anybody would have asked about equality and diversity policies and practices on those projects was unheard of, but I really have seen a sea change in the last two or three years.
In particular, people are actually now beginning to take it seriously.
The projects themselves will have.
Your policy from the start, but they will have activities, actual actions that they are undertaking to consider issues of equality and diversity.
Nancy actually frowning there, but actually I have begun to see this and it is being taken much more seriously, and that's really quite quite nice and.
Comforting anyway.

What kind of work do I do if my my my work is somewhere it's this convergence of what's called human capital and many of you may find that one of those expressions that I know there are some people ideologically hate the notion of human capital.
But taking that as a domain in itself?
Yeah, I'm I'm there.
Sort of in this convergence between human capital knowledge societies.
So the work I do is around technology into working and learning.

Workspace workforce changes, but particularly today I work in this area of trying to put value on human capital and particularly measuring the investment in human capital initiatives in the workplace and what we're really about is asking what difference what business impact is the investment making for the business?
What impact is it making, and is it giving the business value.
And so we're looking at the businesses, organizations, goals and if we look at the public sector, that could be a goal to increase.
For example, in the National Health Service in England, increased paced patient satisfaction.
But it may also be involved in goals of ensuring that the treatment of breast cancer is is addressed earlier and earlier in the treatment.
Life cycle or the potential treatment lifecycle, but it could also be obviously in areas such as profit cost and so forth, which we'll talk about in a minute.
And so when we look at value, we asked the question we spent our money.
What did we get back?
And really, asking the question, was it worth spending the money?

One of the things that led me to this is I've probably evaluated about 2 billion pounds Sterling in the area of adult learning, learning and development workplace workforce changes, and so forth, and I have to say over the years my conclusion is most of it, probably worse wasn't worth spending the money.

And so one of the reasons over the last four or five years we've really developed this, and we work on a very highly defined methodology is to help organisations, whether the governmental, whether their social enterprises, whether private, just if you're going to spend the money, spend it on something that is going to achieve what you want it to achieve, and we we tend to see huge amounts of money being spent that have no outcome or very little outcome.
I'm very little benefit for what was intended, and so we work as I said.

With a very highly refined methodology to help people learn to measure now the kind of stuff we measure in workplaces are obviously knowledge management programs, learning and development programs, performance improvements, change management, and we're working with one bank at the moment.
In the UK BIG Bank, they've had restructuring three times in the last three years.
Last time I was at a meeting with him, I said what?
What are you doing this for?
And they said, nobody knows.
We just keep restructuring and.
It's interesting organizations can't figure out how do we get it right?
They restructure, they do an awful lot of restructuring before they start actually thinking about.
Is this ever going to achieve our intended outcomes?
An actually, what are the intended outcomes are very often part of the problem is people don't really know what it is they're trying to achieve.
We do do some work in equality and diversity and corporate social responsibility areas.

We would like to do more of that, but we've been doing some very interesting work in Africa recently on programs around trying to raise entrepreneurship in some of the East and West African countries.
But behind all of this is every one of these sorts of initiatives that organisations where the public, private and social enterprise undertake.
Somebody has to invest some money going to change something, it's going to cost some money and we are there to ask help people understand.
If you spend the money, what is it you're trying to achieve?
And do we measure?
How do we use good data to demonstrate that we are actually achieving what we set out to?

One of the interesting things about business impact and when I use the term business impact, it's important to think about this in terms of, for instance, we were working with social enterprise recently, whose job or whose role is to provide.
Set up a very caring about secure environments for ex offenders for people who've come out of prison.
And so I was saying, well, what's your what's?
Your key metrics and they said, well just keeping them as ex offenders and not re offenders.
So I said, well, what's an ex offender?
Makes really interesting.
We come back to this issue constantly.
Of what metrics are using what's an ex offender is an ex offender of 15 year old.
Young woman who steals a bracelet and is given a suspended sentence or given a sentence of three months or is an ex offender, a 49 year old who's done 20 years for grievous bodily harm in jail.
One of our huge challenges.
Whether you're talking about the public sphere or the private sphere is that we really bad on deciding what metrics are we using and how do we agree those?
In common, even within organisations we have great challenges.
'cause this is always our starting point.
We say to some one particular organization recently, believe it or not spent £5,000,000 Sterling on leadership development.
So I said, what?
What did you spend it?
What were you trying to do?
Or we want better leaders?
So I said, well, what?
What is a better leader do?
More off or less off for what it had?
How do you know a better leader is going to make the organization achieve its goals?
We just want better leaders.
We'll know by seeing them walk around this kind of nonsense.
This was £5,000,000 Sterling.
Now that's one particular private sector organization, but I have to say I look at huge amounts of public sector investments and they are spending typically in the social Fund.
No recent investment I evaluated spent £7,000,000 Sterling.
I'm trying to do introduce technology to small businesses.
I said how are you going to measure the impact that you've had on this?
Well we have.

We have spent lots of time with lots of businesses, so I said so really all we're doing is measuring how much time you spend with the business is not whether the businesses are going to survive longer, are more competitive, have lower costs, are more efficient.
So we have a huge issue when we set out very often on initiatives in deciding what it is we're doing it for an.
One of the key pieces of our work is to get people to think about what is it that you actually want to change.
What are the measures we've got hard measures and we've got soft measures now in order to measure, we need to have something quite specific.
Units of measure, and it's amazing how difficult it can be for many organisations to actually come down and say this is it.
This is what I want to change, not, you know, people talking lovely sort of broad things, and particularly in the area of human capital.
And it's it is an interesting thing 'cause people will say, well, I don't you.
I don't do measurement.
I'm a people person and I think well people persons fine but people person with £5,000,000 in your budget and you don't do measurement is actually not a very responsible position to be in.
So we have a lot of challenges trying to help people figure out what are we doing this for.
Have you got good data where what?
What is it you want to change?
And how do you actually go about now?
Tracking data around that now it's not simple causality that we look for.
I have to say we've got quite a complex.
We don't have time to go into this today.
Quite a complex chain of impact that we build in terms of pieces of data around engagement, changes of behaviors, business impact.
But we start with this point of let's understand what the metrics are and help people figure out what is it we're actually trying to change.
Do we have stable metrics?
That we need to track.
Where do we find them?
And then in some cases we will look for an economic value associated with those metrics.

Some very easy hard metrics, very easy to convert to monetary value, to monetize some much, much more difficult and a lot of times we say that people don't bother, you know, because it's actually not credible.
It's either not worth it or not credible.
So leave them as soft measures.
The critical thing is to know the measure in the first place.
So be patient, I'm nearly there.
Investment human capital missives usually a couple of other things, so usually accounted as a cost, but not as a cost of sale.
Anybody, whoever looks at accounts, sorry, you're probably going to glaze over now, but it's really it is OK.
It's really interesting if we look at the way we account for these kind of investments, we account for them in a way that allows them to be easily dispensed with.
We don't see them as a cost that's essential for.
The achievement, for instance, of a sale of service in the private sector or the delivery of the service.
We account for them as a dispensable.
What we call an operating cost because they're not considered essential.
They're very easy to get rid of.
And of course, what you find then is you have a downturn in the economy.
Tough times.
You get rid of them.
So all this stuff around equality, special diversity programs.
The minute things get tough, they get because it's really easy and not even though.
Are accounting and tax systems across Europe slightly different?
It's almost always that these costs appear.
What are called below the line.
And as I said, changing patterns of investment difficult times of the economy, they get chopped.
So 2 questions.
Oh sorry, just one other thing.
Because they're not OK. No, I'll come back to.
So these are the.
All questions I was asked to address.
Status of gender policy.
In most international businesses, and I'm only this isn't a scientific study.
This is just our experience.
Most businesses have a policy, but it's almost always based on avoiding risk in relation to regulation.
I very, very rarely come across a policy which is built around business benefit.
In relation to equality and diversity, it's almost always the avoidance of the potential cost.
Because of regulation, compliance policies, and so forth.

Therefore, what happens as you can imagine if you think about it logically, most businesses build a policy largely around regulatory requirements and minimize the cost of anything that they've got to spend on it.
Because the concept of independent business benefit is only about cost avoidance.
So what you do is you see downward pressure on any spending that might be related to something that nobody can justify in business tabs.
So the result is that you get minimum investment both and no business benefit demonstrated, but also minimum investment because no bent business benefit is being dead.
Ministra tidd current activities that go on.
Of course there are some that try and generate evidence of business impact, but most are concerned with regulation requirements.
There's some focus on recruitment in some companies.

If it seems that you know without these types of policies, we're not going to get the talent that we want, but again, because of the way the accounting works around these, those are programs that often get dropped when things get tough.
You may have some kind of arrangements around contracts.

It isn't related to gender, but one of the most interesting things we were asked to look at a while back was the US Department of Defense has contracts defense contracts with different businesses around the world.

One of those was with the company in Belfast, and the interesting thing was that that company in Belfast have a tradition of employing Protestants and US regulations requirements to enter that company.
We can't buy stuff from you if we can't give you defense contracts unless you have an Equal Employment policy.
Catholic and Protestant, so they actually were driven to trying to find ways to employ Catholics because the contract was going to be lossed.
Clear business benefit.
Occasionally you will get that in relation to equality and diversity, but I don't see too many of those.

You may also we've got one case study that we recently worked with somebody from a government Department where they had special Mobility program that they invested in to try and bring a higher proportion of women up to senior management.
But again, it was public sector.
It wasn't private sector and there were some questions about whether they were going to continue it.
Or not, because it wasn't clearly evident, it wasn't evident there weren't.
There wasn't yet good data to show that it was actually making a difference.
Lots of money being spent, but there were still too few people too few women in higher places.
So two questions people will constantly ask what are we doing this for and was it worth it?
And these are always going to be influenced by both the firm performance and the economic climate.
And of course the amount of investment.

Problems and around because most organizations view equality and diversity and I tend to use the term equality and diversity rather than den door equal OPS 'cause it very much for us is around a broader dimension of equality and diversity.
Most see them in terms most.
See firms we deal with C. Vestment in any kind of equality and diversity is initiatives, primarily in terms of regulation as I mentioned, and therefore as an imposed cost.

Because of that, without evidence of benefit very often they minimize the amount of costs investment that they have to spend, and therefore very often you get very poor quality results because they've obviously gone for the cheapest option.
How many you know?
How little can we spend in order to take the boxes, basically?

For those of you who perhaps come from a different ideological background, you may dispute this, but I know having run a business, you have to make, you can call it a surplus, or you can call it a profit.
But if you don't make a surplus of a profit, you don't have a future.
You need to have a reserve, and you need to have something that you can actually use to pay your staff yourself.
And I've gone through several years of not paying myself.

In order to pay other people, and I know the importance of having made a profit in the past in order to have a reserve so that I can actually eat so you know whether whether you have a different ideological view or not, businesses need to make a surplus in order to stay in business, and so questions are going to always be asked around this investment.
It's a cost.
It's treated as a cost if it doesn't show business benefit, it's always going to be questioned.
And we continue to have this issue.
I'm afraid with AMD.
So solutions we need more and better organisations, specific impact studies we have and we do what we don't need.
And forgive me, all of those of you who are academics is we don't need individual academic studies that try and do either macro or meth meter level using lots of different methodology's.
We need standard methodology.
We need standard metrics.
We need everybody to be working on the same metrics.
And we need them to be organisations specific.
We need to help organisations see.
Yes that's gonna deliver this in terms of the business that will not deliver that in terms of the business.
I think there are two other things the public sector is amazingly LAX as it's in its role as a contractor.
As I said, US Department of Defense demand there's an equal distribution.
Catholics and Protestants in defense companies, Huawei is the public sector, not.
Actually using its purchasing power to require businesses to have better equality and diversity, then it becomes a business issue are you get the contractor.
I don't get the contract, it's a simple, very simple result, but unfortunately we don't see that.
Also I have to say I think looking and I'm obviously speaking primarily across the UK, though I do work a lot in other countries, mainly 'cause we work with global businesses.
The public sector isn't always great.
I look at the the equality and diversity practices in the public sector.
There very often actually certainly know better and very far worse than in the private sector.
So efforts to show real to really raise up gender equality, for instance, is no more evident to me in many public sector companies.
That is in private.
An I think anybody who's championing the case for equality and diversity has to accept that economic justification is necessary.
You just have to accept it because business won't listen unless they can see the benefit of it.
So thank you very much indeed.
Thank you very much questions.
Yes.
About another example, such as the one you mentioned in relation to the Catholics and Protestants, yes.
Would there?
Would you have any kind of examples which would be related to employ more women or something like that and have a benefit?
This Sir Sir plus value.
Well it was great pics.
Actually I have it there if anybody wants to have a read of it from the woman who's the president worldwide of Pensacola and she takes the view that.
It is important to invest in.
Typically in women.
Programs and initiatives to support women as parents.
So she has a view that it's business beneficial for her to be seen by a as in order to attract talent and be to be seen by her customers as having an.
I'm more family friendly and So what you do get occasionally in predicting consumer organisations.
And we've seen some ice.

In some cases it's from northern Europe from the Nordic countries, for instance, and this also applies to age related policies that they've adopted that they can see quite clearly for business benefit of having a good diversity program in place.
But the truth is, most of the ones that we see and we do deal with lots and lots of companies.
Most of them are doing it 'cause they have to.
I'm not doing it because they have to put regulation, search and and So what they do is they just.
You know I've ticked the boxes they roll out knee learning program.
I've done it, check the boxes.
Don't know if anybody's change their behavior, but I've seen the boxes cheapest solution 'cause that's what I'm required to do.
Kind of depressing picture.
Question, but first I'd just like to add 1 experience the other day I'm calling to find coffee.
Thank you said would you join me in the port of directors in my company?
He said, well, I started working with the Legion Company and they require 40% of women at work, so I absolutely.
There's a business benefit, and the point is, if you don't show the business benefit, you're not going to find it easy.
You can even drive.
Changes in minimal changes impacts, but you'll never change behavior unless you deliver business evidencing the question that they want.

This is what I'm experiencing that there is a correlation with with a number of women engaged in a process of decision making and strategy formulation and the I call it evolution phase with the companies in.
In other words, if that innovation is already substantially contributed to that very creation, then we see more women.

If we're still in a very so-called working environment where primary the the value creation is driven by technological improvements in productivity, then hardly none are in decision making positions, but one of, you know, just anything.
I think it's very interesting.
Point one of the problems we've got is that, for tax reasons, different countries treat innovation investment differently.
Some of that treated.
You can gain tax benefits from it.

Some new card and so our Indian innovation investment tends to get treated rather differently and so it has less vulnerability in the sense that it's treated in a slightly different way by organisations.
So we see.
But in terms of correlations between innovation and women's employment or women's role at the more decision-making level, certainly I haven't seen anything of that nature.
I do think there are lots of interesting as we talked earlier, lots of interesting potential to do.
Really good evaluation.
I just wanted to add one other thing.
One of these we do is we teach people how to do this for themselves.
Just get better at making decisions we try not to go in and do it for them.
We say get used to collecting data tracking data using data for good decision-making.
Don't tell me you like touchy feely stuff and you're all people.
People use the data.
Gather the data.
Use the data that make decisions based on data and it is interesting in that earlier conversation there is a tendency 'cause a lot of the women a lot of people that we deal with quickly.
For instance, in HRR women and they said we don't need data, we don't.
You know, I know it's numbers and we can't do that, and we're saying if you don't do that, you will never be taken seriously.
Any other questions?
Mark, that we're coming from different ideological background.
I go back to the socialist Self managing system.
It was also based on economic.
Yes quirements.
Call to capital.
Profit.
Yes, come was allocated for different purposes, yes.

And of course there was something like like profit that should be allocated also, but for the technological advancement from new technologies for new knowledge requirements and everything, but you know the problem was only in that that of course there were some.
Other notions also and requirements included, which was from the SoC perspective.
Visibility and development reasons, yes, so it was all within that.
Therefore it was called also social ownership.
Yes, now what would you give the advantage either to have high high profit?
And no education for for your workers and new technologies.
So what is actually then the image of a very successful business?
One of the things I mentioned, we can't.
We don't have time here to go into the complexity of the methodology, but the starting point on our methodology is are you engaged?
Is everybody actually in the workplace?
Who is the target of this initiative engaged in it?
Do they see the relevance?
Do they have the knowledge and tools that they need to carry out this initiative or their role in this list?
If so, I think it's for us what I said earlier.
We we avoid trying to look for causality.
We build chain of impact through the engagement of all involved.

Whether they have the knowledge and skills to actually carry out the role, are they changing their behavior because they understand the point of it and they see the relevance and they're engaged in it and therefore do we get the business results?
So we're building we're building impact data that goes all the way through engagement, learning, behavior change, and business impact.
Now that doesn't directly answer your question, but the point about it is one of the things we're trying to do is actually improve.
The quality of the working lives of the people.
There's no point in throwing 5,000,000 pounds at a leadership development that nobody to use a technical term gives a shit about.
Pizza is completely pointless.
It's a waste of everybody's money so engaged with people, that's what that's the starting point that we say.
Figure out why you want to do this and then engage with your workforce and then we build a chain of impact.
Much like self manage exist about Italian cute, but what is happening today in Slovenia is that mainly you listening to radio television.
Read the newspapers and want to get to the image.
The labor cost is too high.
The workers they live with three 50 to 400.
Net income yes per per month and the labor is still too too costly.
Yes.
And when just by chance somebody mentioned yes but we have four generations old technology and this is not later than the cost.
So what?
What is that?
That's why I'm asking, but of course the profit.
Is the only one only got that they present?
Pushing gets against workers and and their their lives making these are.

EU and NSF funded programs please change the forces.
Thank you very much, Charlie.
I can't tell you what pleasure is been actually being here in the last couple of days.
It's.
I moved to live in the UK at the end of 99 and 98 beginning of 99 prior to that had lived in Ireland and spent three or four days a week in Brussels for a number of years.
I one of the things I realized when I moved to the UK in the first year to 18 months, particularly there was how much I missed the company of women.
And that is that is interesting.
My adult life in particular has been hugely enriched by the Company of women, and I think sometimes we don't celebrate enough.
How much?
We enrich one another's lives, and it's a great pleasure to spend a great pleasure being here in the company of great women.
Lots of different shades and views, and so forth, but it's been very nice.
I thought very long and hard, but what I had to contribute to this debate when you invited me on.
I think I'm going to say.

I run this small company in Cambridge.
It is actually rapidly growing.
One of my challenges at the moment is how do I manage a fast growing business and most of our customers.
Most of our clients are big multinationals.
The big telecoms, the big banks.
Big engineering companies.
Those kinds of businesses.
I've been self-employed since 1993.

Firstly, I ran a business in Ireland between 93 and 99 and then just explaining earlier my my children had grown up at that point and after what my now husband calls an 18 year feasibility study, I decided to get married again and he happened to live in Cambridge.
So I ended up moving to Cambridge because we had family obligations to his family and it was a very good thing to do.
But I've I've always been rather unemployable.
I think that's the truth.
I tried to start my own business at 19.
Had no idea how to set up a business, but but did it anyway.
And then I went back to University and stayed in academic life for a bit and then I haven't had a three and a four year old.
Then I needed to earn a living for us full time and for lots of reasons I went back into.
I went into business.
I went into economic development.
And then I went back into being self employed and running my own business, but I think largely I'm one of those people who always asked the question.
Why are we doing this?
And there's it's not.
It's not for a little while.
Most businesses quite like people who challenge the status quo.

But if you get to be known as the person who's always asking the question, always saying why aren't they wearing any clothes when everybody says their magnificently dressed, then you get to be troublesome.
And you realize, actually, I'm better off as a self employed or running my own business?
'cause actually I'm more disruptive.

And the interesting thing is I've discovered since I've been self employed or running my own businesses, people are prepared to pay me quite a lot of money to come and say, why aren't you wearing any clothes?
Which is quite ironic and it's one of the great ironies of consulting that you know, you can't say it inside, but you can often say it from outside.
The other thing I wanted was part of what I've done right.
The way through the 1990s and right up until her within three or four weeks ago, I think was the last.
Framework program I've been involved in evaluating framework projects.
Also involved in evaluating social fund programs.
Social Fund progress on program projects and as mentioned earlier, and a little bit of work for the National Science Foundation, that's an evaluator as well.
And I've seen a lot of investment and my area of domain is largely around learning and development.
Learning at work knew workplace changes, ways of working.
There has been from time to time a specific gender dimension, but most of the programs I run.
Oh, evaluate on related to specifically to gender issues, so would be about knowledge, SoC information, SoC learning, development, adult learning, workplace learning and I have to say just.
One of the things I have notice around gender is that today, as an evaluator of framework programs, we tend to take equality and diversity issues much more seriously.
I remember the first time I was brought in as evaluator at the end of the Esprit program, she long time ago.
I was for years.

Actually, I would be the only woman in the room of maybe 12:15 twenty people both presenting projects and evaluating, and the idea that anybody would have asked about equality and diversity policies and practices on those projects was unheard of, but I really have seen a sea change in the last two or three years.
In particular, people are actually now beginning to take it seriously.
The projects themselves will have.
Your policy from the start, but they will have activities, actual actions that they are undertaking to consider issues of equality and diversity.

Comforting anyway.

What kind of work do I do if my my my work is somewhere it's this convergence of what's called human capital and many of you may find that one of those expressions that I know there are some people ideologically hate the notion of human capital.
But taking that as a domain in itself?
Yeah, I'm I'm there.
Sort of in this convergence between human capital knowledge societies.
So the work I do is around technology into working and learning.

Workspace workforce changes, but particularly today I work in this area of trying to put value on human capital and particularly measuring the investment in human capital initiatives in the workplace and what we're really about is asking what difference what business impact is the investment making for the business?
What impact is it making, and is it giving the business value.
And so we're looking at the businesses, organizations, goals and if we look at the public sector, that could be a goal to increase.
For example, in the National Health Service in England, increased paced patient satisfaction.
But it may also be involved in goals of ensuring that the treatment of breast cancer is is addressed earlier and earlier in the treatment.
Life cycle or the potential treatment lifecycle, but it could also be obviously in areas such as profit cost and so forth, which we'll talk about in a minute.
And so when we look at value, we asked the question we spent our money.
What did we get back?
And really, asking the question, was it worth spending the money?

One of the things that led me to this is I've probably evaluated about 2 billion pounds Sterling in the area of adult learning, learning and development workplace workforce changes, and so forth, and I have to say over the years my conclusion is most of it, probably worse wasn't worth spending the money.

And so one of the reasons over the last four or five years we've really developed this, and we work on a very highly defined methodology is to help organisations, whether the governmental, whether their social enterprises, whether private, just if you're going to spend the money, spend it on something that is going to achieve what you want it to achieve, and we we tend to see huge amounts of money being spent that have no outcome or very little outcome.
I'm very little benefit for what was intended, and so we work as I said.

With a very highly refined methodology to help people learn to measure now the kind of stuff we measure in workplaces are obviously knowledge management programs, learning and development programs, performance improvements, change management, and we're working with one bank at the moment.
In the UK BIG Bank, they've had restructuring three times in the last three years.
Last time I was at a meeting with him, I said what?
What are you doing this for?
And they said, nobody knows.
We just keep restructuring and.
It's interesting organizations can't figure out how do we get it right?
They restructure, they do an awful lot of restructuring before they start actually thinking about.
Is this ever going to achieve our intended outcomes?
An actually, what are the intended outcomes are very often part of the problem is people don't really know what it is they're trying to achieve.
We do do some work in equality and diversity and corporate social responsibility areas.

We would like to do more of that, but we've been doing some very interesting work in Africa recently on programs around trying to raise entrepreneurship in some of the East and West African countries.
But behind all of this is every one of these sorts of initiatives that organisations where the public, private and social enterprise undertake.
Somebody has to invest some money going to change something, it's going to cost some money and we are there to ask help people understand.
If you spend the money, what is it you're trying to achieve?
And do we measure?
How do we use good data to demonstrate that we are actually achieving what we set out to?

'cause this is always our starting point.

In most international businesses, and I'm only this isn't a scientific study.
This is just our experience.
Most businesses have a policy, but it's almost always based on avoiding risk in relation to regulation.
I very, very rarely come across a policy which is built around business benefit.
In relation to equality and diversity, it's almost always the avoidance of the potential cost.
Because of regulation, compliance policies, and so forth.

Therefore, what happens as you can imagine if you think about it logically, most businesses build a policy largely around regulatory requirements and minimize the cost of anything that they've got to spend on it.
Because the concept of independent business benefit is only about cost avoidance.
So what you do is you see downward pressure on any spending that might be related to something that nobody can justify in business tabs.

Catholic and Protestant, so they actually were driven to trying to find ways to employ Catholics because the contract was going to be lossed.
